events.title: Martin Luther's Ninety-Five Theses
events.description: Martin Luther nailed his Ninety-Five Theses to the door of the Wittenberg Castle church, challenging the Catholic Church's practices and sparking the Protestant Reformation.
events.significance: This act is widely regarded as the beginning of the Protestant Reformation, leading to significant religious, cultural, and political changes in Europe.

events.title: The Sand Creek Massacre
events.description: A tragic massacre occurred in Colorado Territory where U.S. troops attacked and destroyed a village of Cheyenne and Arapaho people, killing many, including women and children.
events.significance: The event intensified conflicts between Native American tribes and the U.S. government, highlighting the brutal realities of American westward expansion.

events.title: Howard Carter Unseals Tutankhamun's Tomb
events.description: British archaeologist Howard Carter and his team unsealed the burial chamber of the Egyptian Pharaoh Tutankhamun in the Valley of the Kings.
events.significance: This discovery was one of the most significant archaeological findings, providing unprecedented insight into ancient Egyptian culture and burial practices.

events.title: Sudan Gains Independence
events.description: Sudan officially gained independence from joint British-Egyptian rule, becoming a sovereign nation.
events.significance: Sudan's independence marked a major step in the decolonization of Africa and the reshaping of post-colonial nations.

events.title: The First Gulf War Ends
events.description: Iraq formally accepted United Nations resolutions, leading to the end of the Gulf War after a decisive coalition victory.
events.significance: The end of the Gulf War reshaped Middle Eastern geopolitics and demonstrated the effectiveness of multinational coalitions under the UN umbrella.
